description: Unknown. Some authorities derive this word from Mexican Spanish jacal, from Nahuatl xacalli (“adobe hut”).
Alternatively, the word may instead come from ramshackle/ramshackly (e.g., old ramshackly house) or perhaps it may be a back-formation from shackly.

entries.meaning: A crude, roughly built hut or cabin.
Any poorly constructed or poorly furnished building.
(slang) The room from which a ham radio operator transmits.

verbs.description: shack (third-person singular simple present shacks, present participle shacking, simple past and past participle shacked)

entries.meaning: To live (in or with); to shack up.

description: Obsolete variant of shake. Compare Scots shag (“refuse of barley or oats”).

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Grain fallen to the ground and left after harvest.
(obsolete) Nuts which have fallen to the ground.
(obsolete) Freedom to pasturage in order to feed upon shack.
examples: […]  first comes the case of tenants with a customary right to shack their sheep and cattle who have overburdened the fields with a larger number of beasts than their tenement entitles them to, or who have allowed their beasts to feed in the field out of shack time.

entries.meaning: (UK, US, dialect, obsolete) A shiftless fellow; a low, itinerant beggar; a vagabond; a tramp.
examples: All the poor old shacks about the town found a friend in Deacon Marble.

entries.meaning: (fishing) Bait that can be picked up at sea.
(Nigeria, slang) A drink, especially an alcoholic one.

verbs.description: shack (third-person singular simple present shacks, present participle shacking, simple past and past participle shacked)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To shed or fall, as corn or grain at harvest.
(obsolete) To feed in stubble, or upon waste.
examples: […]  first comes the case of tenants with a customary right to shack their sheep and cattle who have overburdened the fields with a larger number of beasts than their tenement entitles them to, or who have allowed their beasts to feed in the field out of shack time.

entries.meaning: (UK, dialect) To wander as a vagabond or tramp.
(US, intransitive) To hibernate; to go into winter quarters.
